data.title: description
data.text: A resistor limits the flow of electrical current through a circuit.

data.title: how it work
data.text: A resistor uses up some of a circuit's current and converts it into heat. It does this by giving the electricity a longer, thinner, and slightly less conductive path to travel. Resistors are used in all kinds of circuits, from helping LEDs keep from burning out, to adjusting the frequency of a radio signals.

data.title: Connect it
data.text: A resistor has two wire leads, and should be connected in series with the device it's meant to support. Resistors are not polarized, which means you can connect them either way around and they will work the same.

data.title: How it is used
data.text: Select the device to edit its name and resistance.

data.title: Get started
data.text: Drag the starter circuit below into your design for a working example of how to use this part.

data.title: More information
data.text: Additional information about resistors and how they are used can be found on these pages:

data.title: description
data.text: This device temporarily stores electrical energy. Ceramic “caps” are usually used for small capacitance values.

data.title: how it work
data.text: A capacitor stores electrical energy by collecting charged particles on two conductive plates separated by a nonconductive material, in this case ceramic.

data.title: Connect it
data.text: A capacitor has two wire leads, and can be connected in parallel or series with the device it's meant to support, depending on the application. Ceramic capacitors are not polarized, which means you can connect them either way around, and they will work the same.

data.title: How it is used
data.text: Select the device to edit its name and capacitance.

data.title: Get started
data.text: Drag the starter circuit below into your design for a working example of how to use this part.

data.title: More information
data.text: Additional information about resistors and how they are used can be found on these pages:

data.title: description
data.text: This device temporarily stores electrical energy. Electrolytic “caps” are usually used for large capacitance values.

data.title: how it work
data.text: A capacitor stores electrical energy by collecting charged particles on two conductive plates separated by a nonconductive material, in this case an electrolyte and metal oxide.

data.title: Connect it
data.text: A capacitor has two wire leads, and can be connected in parallel or series with the device it's meant to support, depending on the application. An electrolytic capacitor is polarized, which means it has a positive and negative side that must be connected correctly for it to work.

data.title: How it is used
data.text: Select the device to edit its name and capacitance.

data.title: Get started
data.text: Drag the starter circuit below into your design for a working example of how to use this part.

data.title: More information
data.text: Additional information about resistors and how they are used can be found on these pages:

data.title: description
data.text: A diode is like a one-way valve, allowing current to flow in one direction through a circuit, but not the other.

data.title: how it work
data.text: This device contains semiconductor material that conducts electricity in one direction, but almost completely blocks flow in the opposite direction.

data.title: Connect it
data.text: A diode has two wire leads, and can be connected in parallel or series with the device it's meant to support, depending on the application. Diodes are polarized, which means they each have a positive and negative pole that must be connected in a certain way.

data.title: How it is used
data.text: Select the device to edit its name.

data.title: Get started
data.text: Drag the starter circuit below into your design for a working example of how to use this part.

data.title: More information
data.text: Additional information about resistors and how they are used can be found on these pages:

data.title: description
data.text: AA zener diode allows current to flow backwards through it if a certain voltage is reached.

data.title: how it work
data.text: This device contains semiconductor material that conducts electricity in one direction, but almost completely blocks flow in the opposite direction, unless a certain voltage is exceeded.

data.title: Connect it
data.text: A zener diode has two wire leads, and should be connected in series with the device it's meant to support. Diodes are polarized, which means they each have a positive and negative pole that must be connected in a certain way.

data.title: How it is used
data.text: Select the device to edit its name and zener voltage.

data.title: Get started
data.text: Drag the starter circuit below into your design for a working example of how to use this part.

data.title: More information
data.text: Additional information about resistors and how they are used can be found on these pages:

data.title: description
data.text: An inductor is a coil of wire that opposes changes in electrical current.

data.title: how it work
data.text: This device stores energy in a magnetic field when electricity is applied. That magnetic field resists changes to the current flow through the inductor.

data.title: Connect it
data.text: An inductor has two wire leads, and should be connected in series with the device it's meant to support.

data.title: How it is used
data.text: Select the device to edit its name and inductance.

data.title: Get started
data.text: Drag the starter circuit below into your design for a working example of how to use this part.

data.title: More information
data.text: Additional information about resistors and how they are used can be found on these pages:

data.title: description
data.text: This device is a momentary switch.

data.title: how it work
data.text: A pushbutton contains metal contacts that are squished together when the button is pressed, allowing electrical current to flow. This pushbutton has four wire leads, two sets of which are internally connected always, and the two sets touch when the button is pressed.

data.title: Connect it
data.text: Wire one side of the switch to power, and the other side to a microcontroller input pin, as well as to ground through a large resistor. The resistor holds the pin LOW unless the button is pressed, at which point the pin can detect a HIGH signal as it connects to 5V.

data.title: How it is used
data.text: Click the device during simulation to simulate pressing the switch. Press Shift and click the device to simulate holding the switch down.

data.title: Get started
data.text: Drag the starter circuit below into your design for a working example of how to use this part.

data.title: More information
data.text: Additional information about resistors and how they are used can be found on these pages:

data.title: description
data.text: This device is a variable resistor controlled by a knob.

data.title: how it work
data.text: A potentiometer works by changing the position of a movable contact on a resistive material in relation to a stationary contact, resulting in a changing resistance as the contact is moved.

data.title: Connect it
data.text: This device has three wire leads attached to it. Connect the outer pins each to power and Ground, and the Signal pin is connected to a device directly, or any digital or analog terminal on an Arduino.

data.title: How it is used
data.text: Click the device during simulation to highlight it, then click and drag the wiper to change the simulated resistance.

data.title: Get started
data.text: Drag the starter circuit below into your design for a working example of how to use this part.

data.title: More information
data.text: Additional information about resistors and how they are used can be found on these pages:

data.title: description
data.text: This device is a toggle switch with two positions.

data.title: how it work
data.text: A toggle switch contains metal contacts that electrically join when the slider is moved, allowing electrical current to flow.

data.title: Connect it
data.text: This device has three wire leads. Connect the Common pin in the middle to your device. Power and Ground are connected to Terminals 1 and 2; the order determines which direction is ON and which is OFF.

data.title: How it is used
data.text: Click the device during simulation to change the switch position.

data.title: Get started
data.text: Drag the starter circuit below into your design for a working example of how to use this part.

data.title: More information
data.text: Additional information about resistors and how they are used can be found on these pages:

data.title: description
data.text: This device is a variable resistor that reacts to light.

data.title: how it work
data.text: When light energy contacts the sensor, the material absorbs some of the light energy and converts it to electrical energy, becoming less resistive.

data.title: Connect it
data.text: A resistor has two wire leads, and should be connected in series with the device it's meant to control. Photoresistors are not polarized, which means you can connect them either way around.

data.title: How it is used
data.text: Select the device during simulation to show a slider representing light level. Slide the target to change the simulated light level.

data.title: Get started
data.text: Drag the starter circuit below into your design for a working example of how to use this part.

data.title: More information
data.text: Additional information about resistors and how they are used can be found on these pages:

data.title: description
data.text: A photodiode allows current to flow backward through it proportional to the light it absorbs.

data.title: how it work
data.text: This device works like a reverse LED - when the junction of its materials is exposed to light, then electric current or voltage is generated, depending on how it is connected.

data.title: Connect it
data.text: This device has two wire leads and is polarized. It is often connected backward (reverse biased) to read a change in current via a microcontroller's analog input.

data.title: How it is used
data.text: Select the device during simulation to show a slider representing light level. Slide the target to change the simulated light level.

data.title: Get started
data.text: Drag the starter circuit below into your design for a working example of how to use this part.

data.title: More information
data.text: Additional information about resistors and how they are used can be found on these pages:

data.title: description
data.text: An ambient light sensor, or phototransistor, senses changes in light intensity. The flow of electrical current between the emitter and collector varies based on the amount of light received.

data.title: how it work
data.text: This device is an NPN transistor where the base connection is replaced by an optical source. The base current from the photons is amplified by the transistor's gain.

data.title: Connect it
data.text: This device is an NPN transistor where the base connection is replaced by an optical source. The base current from the photons is amplified by the transistor's gain.

data.title: How it is used
data.text: Select the device during simulation to show a slider representing light level. Slide the target to change the simulated light level.

data.title: Get started
data.text: Drag the starter circuit below into your design for a working example of how to use this part.

data.title: More information
data.text: Additional information about resistors and how they are used can be found on these pages:

data.title: description
data.text: This device is a variable resistor that reacts to bending.

data.title: how it work
data.text: The semi-conductive material on this flexible sensor becomes more conductive when it is squeezed together as the sensor flexes.

data.title: Connect it
data.text: This device has two wire leads, and is often connected to the analog input of a microcontroller. Flex sensors are not polarized, which means they can be connected either way around.

data.title: How it is used
data.text: Select the device during simulation and drag it up and down to change its flexing angle.

data.title: Get started
data.text: Drag the starter circuit below into your design for a working example of how to use this part.

data.title: More information
data.text: Additional information about resistors and how they are used can be found on these pages:

data.title: description
data.text: breadboard is a tool used for prototyping electronic circuits without soldering.

data.title: how it work
data.text: A breadboard has holes arranged in a grid pattern. Inside, metal strips connect the holes in rows or columns, allowing components to share electrical connections. Power rails run along the sides for supplying voltage and ground.

data.title: Connect it
data.text: Insert components (resistors, LEDs, ICs, etc.) into the holes.

data.title: How it is used
data.text: Prototyping circuits before soldering.Testing and debugging electronic components.Learning and experimenting with circuit design.

data.title: Get started
data.text: Get a breadboard, jumper wires, and electronic components.Connect a power source (e.g., 9V battery or USB power supply).Follow circuit diagrams to place components.

data.title: More information
data.text: Breadboards come in different sizes (e.g., full-size, half-size, mini).Works best with low-voltage DC circuits.Can be used with microcontrollers like Arduino and Raspberry Pi.

data.title: description
data.text: The BBC micro:bit is a small, programmable microcontroller designed for learning coding and electronics. It features sensors, LEDs, and input/output pins for various projects.

data.title: how it work
data.text: The micro:bit has a 5x5 LED matrix, buttons, a temperature sensor, an accelerometer, and a Bluetooth module. It runs programs written in languages like MakeCode, Python, or JavaScript and can interact with external devices using its input/output (I/O) pins.

data.title: Connect it
data.text: Use a USB cable to connect it to a computer for programming Attach external components (LEDs, motors, sensors) via the edge connector pins or alligator clips

data.title: How it is used
data.text: Games & Interactive Projects: Creating animations, step counters, and music, IoT (Internet of Things): Sending and receiving data via Bluetooth or radio signals.

data.title: Get started
data.text: Choose a coding platform (MakeCode, Python, or JavaScript), Write a simple program (e.g., display a heart on the LED matrix), Download the code and transfer it to the micro:bit via USB.

data.title: More information
data.text: Works with external sensors and motors via the I/O pins, Can communicate with other micro:bits using radio signals.
